awd_titl_txt: CAREER: In Situ Nanomechanics of High-Performance Anode Materials for Sodium-Ion Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program project will characterize the nanomechanical and electrochemical interactions in sodium-ion battery electrode materials and develop constitutive models to elucidate the morphological and structural evolution in these materials. As one of the most widespread technologies for energy storage, lithium-ion batteries have been under intense studies over the past two decades. Sodium-ion batteries are being considered as a low-cost alternative because sodium is much more earth abundant and less geographically constrained than lithium. However, the development of advanced sodium-ion batteries has been hindered by a significant unexplored gap in understanding the mechanics of high-performance electrode materials. The proposed research spans several disciplines, including mechanics, materials science, physics, and electrochemistry. The fundamental understanding obtained in this research will make a profound impact on these disciplines. The multidisciplinary work will train undergraduate and graduate students with a broad range of skills and knowledge, and expose them to the complementary research of experimentation and modeling. The research will also involve K-12 teachers and students, particularly females and minorities, through various outreach programs at the Georgia Institute of Technology. The research results will be integrated into the lab modules of a new course on experimental solid mechanics.

Energy storage and release of sodium-ion battery electrodes involves a complex set of mechanical and electrochemical processes, including deformation, stress generation, mass transport, phase transformation, and chemical reaction. A fundamental understanding of the mechanics and its strong coupling with other physical phenomena is required to achieve breakthroughs in the sodium-ion battery technology. The research objective of this award is to develop an in situ nanomechanical testing platform for the constitutive characterizations of sodium-ion battery electrode materials. The experimental framework will be employed to investigate the in situ mechanics of sodiated/desodiated germanium and germanium-tin alloys, which are two promising high-performance anode materials for advanced sodium-ion batteries. The space- and time-resolved constitutive behaviors from experimental measurements will be incorporated into a continuum computational model for predictive simulations of the mechanical degradation and morphological evolution in solid electrode materials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Reliable, efficient, and cost-effective electrochemical energy storage (EES) materials are the key to revolutionizing the renewable energy sector. The development of better EES technologies, however, is hindered by a lack of fundamental knowledge regarding the intricate constitutive behaviors of EES materials. In the development of next-generation, high-performance rechargeable batteries such as sodium-ion batteries (NIBs), a current challenge is to understand the mechanical characteristics of solid electrodes and their complex coupling with other physical and chemical processes. Such understanding would enable researchers to unravel the dynamic processes of energy storage and release, which features with extremely large deformation inside solid electrodes. This is essential to a rational development of high-capacity electrode materials for next-generation rechargeable batteries.

The research objective of this project is to address the largely unexplored knowledge gap in understanding the chemo-mechanical interplay in large-deformation NIB electrode materials. To achieve this goal, we developed a suite of novel nanomechanical testing tools and applied them to investigate the mechanical characteristics of a range of model material systems, including sodiated germanium, iron disulfide, sodium metal and their lithium counterparts, under well controlled electrochemical conditions. Concurrently, a comprehensive computational model, which accounted for finite strain, elastoplastic flow, as well as full two-way coupling between ion diffusion and mechanical stress, was created for predictive modeling and design of NIB electrodes. Broadly, this integrated experimental and computational study revealed the critical importance of stress-diffusion coupling in governing the deformation and degradation mechanisms of active NIB electrode materials and provided the first framework for characterizing and understanding such coupling.

This project has provided research training to two Ph.D. students and three undergraduate students. The research findings resulting from this project have been disseminated to the scientific community through publication of five peer-reviewed journal papers, with two more papers in preparation. The research team has given more than 25 presentations about this work at conferences and universities locally, nationally, and internationally, including 11 invited talks and seminars.


Last Modified: 05/01/2022
Modified by: Shuman Xia
